intrainingdoc 162562479683 "2017-07-03 20:40:34 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/162562479683/i-need-a-minute "aspiringdoctors: homoglobinopathy:  chelsfournier:  homoglobinopathy:  The nature of our healthcare system has changed. It has become less about making patients better
column2: comfortable
column3: and ensuring they get out of the hospital to go home and not leaving in a casket
column4: to only caring about what they have to say about their ‚Äúexperience‚Äù during their stay. Might as well start putting hospitals on Yelp and Tripadvisor.   Our system focuses too much on patient satisfaction and less on medical skill. Less about doing what is necessary to improve someone‚Äôs medical state and more about doing everything in our power to keep them happy. And worse is Administration across the country is all about this model of practice. So the healthcare systems slap down regulation after regulation to automize us basically turning us into robots. When the medical staff isn‚Äôt walking around on their tip toes trying not to break these outlandish rules that help keep pressgany scores up the level of medical care provided improves.   Currently if our system performs poorly we lose all of our incentive bonuses at the end of the year. Last year we didn‚Äôt get anything yet everyone in admin got over a million dollars in bonus pay. Nurses and Doctors both get fired from patient care because ‚Äúshe didn‚Äôt have a pleasant look on her face‚Äù or ‚Äúthey said I had to stay here another night when another doctor said I could leave I want them and not you
column5: ‚Äù or ‚Äúyou‚Äôre too young to be a well doctor get me someone with some actual experience in here and don‚Äôt you come back.‚Äù   Yes patients deserve to be happy and well taken care of obviously. But when it comes to a point that getting a bad review because we forgot to bring you water due to the fact another patient was actively dying
column6: and then we get more of a lecturing about the negative review instead of figuring out what we could of done better for the other patient‚Ä¶is absurd to me.    Patient satisfaction scores are the literal worst thing to ever happen to healthcare.  Say it louder for the people in administration!   It‚Äôs also proven that chasing patient satisfaction negatively impacts patient care and
column8: practicing good medicine. Ughhhhh.   " False text

column1: intrainingdoc 162411366282 "2017-06-29 22:20:24 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/162411366282/the-truth-behind-stereotypes "dxmedstudent: shrinkrants:  themedicalchronicles:  thedisagreeabledoctor:  While preparing for my next patient I read in her previous note that she ‚Äú..is a¬†Vietnamese immigrant who works at a nail salon.‚Äù ¬†I stifled a laugh as I recalled Dat Phan‚Äôs comedy bit on the Vietnamese taking over the U.S. one foot at a time. ¬†I mentally scolded myself as I tried to dismiss my racist stereotype. ¬†Yet
column2: you cannot deny that this is one stereotype that frequently plays true.¬† She smiled as I entered the room
column3: remaining patient as I fumbled with the pronunciation of her name. ¬†After exchanging pleasantries we discussed her reasons for coming in: a lingering cold and a skin lesion. ¬†I noted that she had missed multiple appointments prior to this
column4: failing to get follow up labs from over a year ago. ¬†She blamed this on her busy schedule
column5: caring for two children and working full-time. ¬†For providers the chronically busy patient can seem as frustrating as the chronically sick patient. Next we proceeded into her exam. ¬†The stigmata for bacterial infection were conspicuously absent. ¬†I described my findings to her
column6: watching her mood deflate slightly when I explained that antibiotics would not help. ¬†I continued to work my way down her body in a systematic exam
column7: explaining as I went. ¬†As I came to her hands I winced. ¬†The skin was thickened
column9: and cracked. ¬†My hands began to hurt in sympathy. ‚ÄúTell me about your hands
column10: ‚Äù I said. She responded in deeply accented English that her hands became like this after working with the nail chemicals all day.¬† ‚ÄúAnd do you like this job?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúI hate it
column11: ‚Äù she responded. ¬†I continued to inquire why
column12: if she hated her job and it hurt her skin in such a terrible way
column13: she did not seek other employment.¬† ‚ÄúIn my country I was a nurse. ¬†But here I would have to start schooling over. ¬†It would take twice as long because I would first have to take English classes.‚Äù She continued to explain that when coming over
column14: many Vietnamese people worked in nail salons because that is where other Vietnamese people worked. ¬†In other words
column15: it was one of the few places they could get a foot in the door as untrained workers who barely spoke discernible English. ¬†Suddenly the Dat Phan comedy bit seemed a lot less funny. ‚ÄúWhy come to the U.S.?‚Äù ¬†I asked. ¬†‚ÄúIf you were a nurse in Vietnam
column16: why immigrate to a place with few job opportunities.‚Äù Her answer? ¬†She makes more here as a nail technician than a nurse in Vietnam
column17: meaning she can send money to her family at home. ¬†And being here gives her two teenage children a better opportunity for employment as they grow up. ¬†In short
column18: this woman gave up a job she enjoyed
column19: to work in conditions she hates
column20: in order for her family to have opportunities she never could. Long after I wrote her note and sent her on her way
column21: my Vietnamese patient lingered in my mind. ¬†Interestingly
column22: the more I thought the more I realized she did fit into a stereotype
column23: although I had placed her in the wrong one. ¬†Perhaps it is partially true to think that many Vietnamese immigrants are nail technicians. ¬†But I think the better way to look at immigrants
column25: is with the lens of selfless hope they often bring with them
column26: rather than the employment circumstances they often find themselves in. ¬†She
column27: like the most tremendous among us
column28: gave up her life goals in order to propel her family into a new socioeconomic class. ¬†That to me doesn‚Äôt fit the image the media promotes for immigrants
column29: but rather the image I think of when I see working class mothers struggling for their family‚Äôs sake. ¬†And I think that stereotype
column30: an example of the best that people have to offer
column31: is a stereotype I can live with.¬†  Reminds me of a post I saw somewhere on Tumblr: Hands up for our parents that came to America with nothing and gave us everything.   Yes to all this
column32: AND let‚Äôs be careful not to fall into the belief that it‚Äôs possible for every immigrant
column33: or every ghetto-ized person of color to pull themselves up by their own bootstraps. We need a living wage
column37: and much more for folks at all levels of our very steep pyramid.  The immigrant experience in a nutshell
column38: for those of you who aren‚Äôt from an immigrant background. " False text

column1: intrainingdoc 162408025917 "2017-06-29 20:40:32 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/162408025917/leaving-after-a-long-exhausting-shift "licensetomurse: boluscoffeestat:  This. This is the perfect gif. " False text

intrainingdoc 162289467067 "2017-06-26 20:40:36 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/162289467067/cranquis-wheresonichedgehogwnt-id-like-to "cranquis: wheresonichedgehogwnt:  I‚Äôd like to make a nomination for Brother of the Year. Today my attending and I called a patient‚Äôs bother and power of attorney.  We explained to him that his brother (who had multiple serious medical comorbidities) had been found in cardiac arrest after an unknown period of time
column2: and while the paramedics had gotten his heart to start beating again
column3: he was in very grave condition and given his multiple other health problems
column4: we didn‚Äôt know what his chances for recovery looked like or what his quality of life would be if he did. The brother stopped us.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a doctor in (Town a few hours away)‚Äù
column6: ‚ÄúAnd he‚Äôs been miserable these past few years
column7: being as sick as he is and going through the treatment he did.  He wouldn‚Äôt want this.  I‚Äôm leaving to drive there as soon as I hang up
column8: but I want you to take the tube out
column10: and if he starts to die before I get there
column11: let him go.  Don‚Äôt put the tube back in
column15: I don‚Äôt want him to suffer any more for my sake.‚Äù I can only imagine how hard that must‚Äôve been for him. We would‚Äôve completely understood if he‚Äôd wanted us to keep his brother intubated until he got here and could be with him as he died
column16: but he wanted us to make and keep him comfortable
column17: instead. If my brother is ever (heaven forbid) in that same situation and I have to make a decision
column18: I hope I‚Äôd have the compassion and strength to tell his docs to put his comfort first and foremost
column19: let his death progress as naturally as it could
column21: and accept that I may not get there in time to see him alive again
column22: but feel it is worth it so I can spare him some suffering.  Sometimes the best gift you can give a loved one is the gift of letting nature take its course. Quantity of life does not always equal quality of life.¬†  *reblogging for the people in the back*" False text

intrainingdoc 162184510402 "2017-06-24 02:35:20 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/162184510402/medblr-question-patient-histories "whitecoat-bluegown:  cranquis:  medschoolmanic:  wayfaringmd:  cranquis:  slowdownsimplybemd:  md-to-md:  I just started my first year of Medical School and we are learning how to take patient histories. I noticed that doctors tend to have certain lines or go-to phrases they say when they address different issues in the conversation
column2: so I‚Äôm wondering if medblrs can reblog this and add some of the things they like to say when taking a history.  (Nurblr responses are welcome too
column3: as are signal boosts
column4: thanks! üòä)  I just learned this too!! Would love to hear about other medblrs tips and tricks!! Any advice @wayfaringmd @pedsblr @surrealmeds @cranquis @imaresident @md-admissions @mymedlife and any other medblrs out there?!  When suspecting prostatitis as a cause for symptoms
column5: I don‚Äôt jump to asking questions about erectile dysfunction
column7: and urinary obstructive symptoms right away. First
column8: I ask the guy if he knows what his prostate is
column9: and then I give a brief description of the prostate: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs basically a racquetball wrapped around the pee-tube coming out from your bladder
column10: and it‚Äôs also next-door neighbors with your rectum. If it‚Äôs enlarged or sick
column11: it can block your urine flow
column12: and it can jack up your sex function. So that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm going to ask you these questions.‚Äù THEN
column13: when they start pinging lots of +‚Äôs on the prostate symptoms (and
column15: answering them more honestly because they know what I‚Äôm getting at)
column17: sure sounds like your prostate could be the cause of your X symptoms
column19: we need to feel it and see if it‚Äôs swollen or tender. Now that you‚Äôre an expert on prostates
column20: can you guess how we examine it?‚Äù Believe it or not
column21: my male patients seem to be overall less embarrassed and apprehensive about digital rectal exams if THEY are the first one in the room to say ‚Äúfinger in the butthole‚Äù‚Ä¶ because by that point
column22: they understand WHY it‚Äôs important to do this.¬†  Never ask ‚Äúare you missing any doses
column23: ‚Äù but rather ‚Äúhow often do you miss a dose?‚Äù Nobody is perfect. Let‚Äôs acknowledge that so your patient doesn‚Äôt feel like they have to lie.  When you run out of questions or blank out
column24: always feel free to ask ‚Äúis there anything else you think I should know that I haven‚Äôt asked?‚Äù It will give you a few more seconds to think.  In regards to pain complaints
column25: always ask ‚Äúwhat were you doing when it started?‚Äù It may be useless
column26: but you‚Äôd be surprised how often you see people for neck pain who have no clue what caused it and when you ask that question they say ‚Äúpainting my ceiling‚Äù. I usually start my preventive care visits with ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to ask you a bunch of nosy personal questions today so I can figure out what sort of diseases you might be at risk for. If at any time you think I‚Äôve gone too far
column28: or if you have a question why I would ask about XYZ
column29: please ask.‚Äù  When asking about anxiety
column30: I usually ask people how they feel physically when they‚Äôre really anxious. I will explain that my heart beats extra hard and fast when I‚Äôm anxious
column31: whereas some people get an upset stomach or shortness of breath. Often that helps zoom in on some somatic issues.  If a person has a series of vague complaints or they come in for fatigue
column32: always always ask about sleep habits. Patients will roll their eyes and say they sleep fine and then admit they sleep 4 hours a night because they keep checking Facebook all night.  If you‚Äôre asking about a distance
column33: like how far a person can walk before they have to stop and rest
column34: try using relative terms like ‚Äúfrom this room to the front desk‚Äù or ‚Äúacross the Walmart parking lot‚Äù rather than accurate distances like 100 yards or a half mile. Folks often don‚Äôt have much perspective on how far 100 feet is.  Also: I second Cranquis‚Äô use of basic
column35: easy to understand terms like ‚Äúpee tube‚Äù and ‚Äújack up your sex function‚Äù. You and the patient will both know what you mean. However
column36: when a patient uses vague terms like ‚Äúmy down-there‚Äù areas or ‚Äúmy privates
column37: ‚Äù make sure you can get them to be more specific. For example
column38: if a woman complains of pelvic pain
column39: specify is it deep in the abdomen like menstrual cramps
column40: on the skin outside the vagina like a rash
column41: inside the vagina like a yeast infection
column42: etc.  That‚Äôs alls I can think of right now.  My addition is related to asking about mental health. My program (stupidly) focuses on not using the words¬†‚Äúmental health‚Äù or ‚Äúpsychiatrist‚Äù when asking about history of depression
column45: etc. because of the¬†‚Äústigma‚Äù associated with having to see a mental health professional. I find this extremely ironic because their approach to lessening the stigma associated with mental healthcare is by trying to tiptoe around it by asking questions like¬†‚ÄúHave you ever seen anyone for in the past for any sort of anxiety or depression?‚Äù The problem with asking about a mental health history in this manner is that it leaves out a multitude of other reasons someone may have seen a therapist
column47: or counselor. All aspects of mental health are extremely important
column48: and by focusing on only two diagnoses (anxiety and depression) I feel that leaves out a lot of other conditions my patient might have
column49: ranging from schizophrenia to arousal disorders.¬† So
column51: ¬†‚ÄúAt any point in your life have you seen a mental health professional or counselor for any reason?‚Äù And it shouldn‚Äôt be uncomfortable. Not for you. Not for the patient. I have never once had a patient get offended by me asking about their mental health history. I hate this idea that we can‚Äôt say¬†‚Äúmental health‚Äù because of the stigma associated with the phrase¬†‚Äúmental health.‚Äù We won‚Äôt get rid of a stigma by avoiding the phrase entirely. If anything it just worsens it.¬†  This thread keeps getting better and better. Check out the entry by @md-admissions in a separate reblog too.¬†  This is fantastic! I‚Äôll add some peds stuff because that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm on right now:‚Ä®‚Äìif your patient is old enough to talk
column52: ask them who they brought with them. Like
column53: point at the adult in the room and say ‚Äúwho is that?‚Äù It gives you a ton of insight into their social situation without having to ask awkward questions‚Äìfor example
column54: the person you may have assumed was mom is actually auntie and now you have a perfect opening to casually ask where mom is. It‚Äôs also fantastic because kids will always say things like ‚Äúthat‚Äôs Dad
column55: ‚Äù and you also call the father ‚ÄòDad
column56: ‚Äô which is a cheap but effective way to get a laugh out of a school age kids.‚Ä®‚Äìwhen you‚Äôre asking about developmental history
column57: especially in the inpatient/urgent care/ER seeing
column58: ask if anyone has ever been concerned about the child‚Äôs growth or development. It‚Äôs a quick way to assess for any major issues
column59: then you can go through age-appropriate screening as needed. A surprisingly high number of people have told me that
column61: little Johnny did need speech therapy for a year now that you think about it. ‚Ä®‚ÄìSocial history in teens is super awkward
column62: always. I start the conversation by asking about what their friends are doing‚Äìkids are much more likely to admit that their friends are drinking than tell you about their own drinking habits. It also gives you a great judgement-free avenue for education‚Äìyou can talk about stupid things their friends have done while drinking and how to avoid them while still reinforcing to the teen that drinking can be dangerous.  This is beautiful. Keep on keeping on!" False text

column1: intrainingdoc 162135611819 "2017-06-22 20:40:16 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/162135611819/jekyll-and-hyde-cells-their-role-in-brain-injury "neurosciencestuff: New  research has shown how normally helpful brain cells can turn rogue and  kill off other brain cells following injury or disease. (Image caption:  Astrocytes are shedding light on neurodegeneration caused by a range of diseases) Astrocytes  have long been implicated in the pathology of a range of human  neurodegenerative diseases or injuries including Alzheimer‚Äôs
column2: Huntington‚Äôs Parkinson‚Äôs disease
column3: brain trauma and spinal cord injury. But how they are produced and what their roles in disease may be
column4: has been as yet unknown. This paper  provides an understanding of the mechanism involved and for the first  time provides hope that a lot of these diseases may in fact be  treatable. The study
column5: published recently in Nature and led by  researchers at The University of Melbourne and Stanford University
column6: provides deeper understanding of the functions of injured or  diseased astrocytes found in the Central Nervous System (CNS) following  acute injury and chronic neurodegenerative disease. In a healthy brain
column7: astrocytes are vital for the normal functioning  of the brain - providing nutrients to support neuron viability
column8: releasing factors that aid formation of connections between nerve  cells known as synapses
column9: as well as many other important functions. One puzzle has been that in some circumstances the astrocytes appear  to have a toxic effect on neurons
column10: whereas in others they support  neuronal viability and connectivity. Researcher Dr Shane Liddelow from the University of Melbourne‚Äôs  Department of Pharmacology and Therapeutics
column11: and the Department of  Neurobiology at Stanford University
column12: said astrocytes are often  characterised as ‚Äòhelper‚Äô cells but they can also contribute to damage  caused by brain injury and disease by turning toxic and kill other types  of brain cells. ‚ÄúThese apparently opposing effects have been a puzzle for some time.  By characterising two types of astrocytes this paper provides some  answers to the puzzle
column14: astrocytes form scar tissue that can help in  the regeneration of severed fibres. But we have also discovered that  under certain conditions
column15: they can turn and become negatively reactive
column17: ‚Äù Dr Liddelow said For many decades
column18: the trauma and neurodegeneration research focus has  been on neurons. Researchers are excited by the discovery of these  neurotoxic reactive astrocytes
column20: these  findings imply that acute injuries of the retina
column21: brain and spinal cord  and chronic neurodegenerative diseases
column22: may all be much more treatable  and even reversible than first thought. By providing new insights into the process of neurodegeneration
column23: researchers can look at new pathways for dealing with neurological  diseases and injuries
column25: in addition  to neurones in neuropsychiatric diseases or oligodendrocytes as for  instance in multiple sclerosis. Ultimately
column26: there is still hope that one day it may be possible to  switch back astrocytes from the ‚Äútoxic‚Äù to the ‚Äúhelper‚Äù state
column27: a long  term target for Dr. Liddelow and colleagues. " False text

column7: even though my shift was over at 7 PM‚ÄìI wasn‚Äôt going to abandon my patient in the middle of pushing
column8: and we weren‚Äôt going to c-section because the baby looked great and the patient didn‚Äôt want to and they were making process (albeit slowly)

column12: healthy mom and baby. I‚Äôm not saying there aren‚Äôt bad doctors who aren‚Äôt selfish

column14: nor am I passive-aggressively putting down CNMs

column1: intrainingdoc 161942479138 "2017-06-17 22:20:10 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/161942479138/10-mistakes-when-studying "howtostudyquick:  1. ‚ÄúI Don‚Äôt Know where to Begin.‚Äù Make a list of all the things you have to do. Break your workload down ito manageable chunks. Prioritize. Schedule your time realistically. Begin studying early
column2: with an hour or two per day
column3: and slowly build as the exam approaches.  2. ‚ÄòI‚Äôve Got So Much to Study‚Ä¶And so Little Time"" Preview. Survey your syllabus
column5: and notes. Identify the most important topics emphasized
column6: and areas still not understood. Previewing saves time
column7: by helping you organize and focus in on the main topics.  3. ‚ÄúThis Stuff is so Dry
column8: I can‚Äôt Even Stay Awake Reading It‚Äù Get actively involved with the text as you read. Ask yourself
column9: ‚ÄúWhat is important to remember about this section?‚Äù Take notes or underline key concepts. Discuss the material with others in your class. Stay on the offensive.  4. ‚ÄúI Read It. I Understand It. But I Just Can‚Äôt Get it To Sink In‚Äù Elaborate. We remember best the things that are most meaningful to us. As you are reading
column10: try to elaborate upon new information with your own examples. Try to integrate what you‚Äôre studying with what you already know. You will be able to remember new material better if you can link it to something that‚Äôs already meaningful to you.  Chunking: Example: to remember the colors in the visible spectrum
column11: Rog G.Biv ‚Äì> reduce the information the three ‚Äúchunks‚Äù. Mnemonics: Associate new information with something familiar.  5. ‚ÄúI Guess I Understand It‚Äù Test yourself. Make up questions about key sections in notes or reading. Examine the relationships between concepts and sections. Often
column12: imply by changing section headings you can generate many effective questions. 6. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs Too Much to Remember‚Äù Organize. Information is recalled better if it is represented in an organized framework that will make retrieval more systematic.  Write chapter outlines of summaries; emphasize relationships between sections.  Group information into categories or hierarchies
column13: where possible. Information Mapping. Draw up a matrix to organize and interrelate material.  7. ‚ÄúI Knew It A Minute Ago‚Äù Review. After reading a section
column14: try to recall the information contained in it. Try answering the questions you made up for that section. If you cannot recall enough
column15: re-read portions you had trouble remembering. The more time you spend studying
column16: the more you tend to recall. Even after the point where information can be perfectly recalled
column17: further study makes the material less likely to be forgotten entirely. How you organize and integrate new information is still more important than how much time you spend studying.    For more follow How To Study Quick!!  " False text

It is perfectly possible to look beyond  this unfortunate circumstance and find inspiration
column2: even in an  oxymoronic sense. I seek not to lighten the seriousness of depression
column3: but to lighten the burden imposed on those fighting it.¬†To those who can  relate
column4: your journey is unique and may differ from mine
column5: but  remember that there is always a silver lining. A negatively charged  electron inherently attracts a positive proton as the universe moves  toward equilibrium. As such
column6: it is the hardships and the sufferings we  face as both medical students and human beings that bring out the best  qualities in us and help mold the physician that we eventually become.‚ÄùMollika Hossain at Florida State University College of Medicine talks about the silver lining in medicine when battling depression." column1: intrainingdoc 162707876967 "2017-07-07 14:00:23 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/162707876967/adventure-11-cooking-mama "‚ÄúI might be biased
column2: not having had home-cooked food in a long time
column3: but  that was one of my favorite adventures thus far. Yes
column4: the people I was  with and the environment I was cooking in was excellent
column5: but I was most  pleasantly surprised by the addition of a new skill into my repertoire ‚Äî  how to make tasty and nutritious treats. Cooking is quite an  undervalued skill and knowing at least a couple of nifty recipes that  take less than 15 minutes will be valuable to you as a medical student  and even beyond. If for only that reason
column6: I‚Äôd highly recommend everyone  take a cooking class at some point. It‚Äôs fun
